_prev_prog_3.Description: No 2 CRU - Catalytic reforming converts low-octane naphtha into high-octane blendstock used to make gasoline.  The No 2 CRU also removes sulfur containing compounds by hydrogenation to meet gasoline sulfur specifications.  High & low shutdowns & alarms on major pieces or rotating equipment (ie. recycle & desulfurizer compressor) in this process coupled with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Benzene Reduction:  The Benzene Reduction Unit decreases the benzene content of light straight run (LSR) gasoline.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Sat Gas Plant - The Saturate Gas process separates the lightest portions from the crude topping process.  Propane, butane, and light gasoline are the principal products. The residue gas is fuel for the refinery furnaces.  High/low shutdowns on major pieces of reciprocating equipment (ie. engine driven compressors) in this process coupled with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 2 CTU - The No 2 Crude process separates crude oil by fractional distillation.  Resulting raw products include: unstabilized gasoline, naphtha, kerosene, heating oil, distillate, atmospheric gas oil, light vacuum gas oil, heavy vacuum gas oil & vacuum tar.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 3 CRU/HDS - Catalytic Reforming is a process in which low-octane naphtha is converted to a high-octane blendstock used to make gasoline. Hydrogen, butane, and other lighter hydrocarbons are also produced.  High & low shutdowns & alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie.  motor driven reciprocating compressors and associated drivers) in this process together with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of  catastrophic failures.

No 4 FCC - The Fluidized Catalytic Cracking process (FCC) converts  gas oils (a viscous material similar to motor oil) into blendstocks used to make gasoline and diesel fuel.  Co-products include: heating oil, slurry, butane, and lighter products to be used by other units in the refinery.  High & low shutdowns & alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie. air blower, centrifugal wet gas compressor, &  refrigerant compressor and associated drivers) in this process along with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Amine Regeneration - This process produces Lean amine for:  1)the Sat Gas process, 2) the HDS processes, 3) The fuel gas contactor & 4) for the P-P Treater.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 1 Cryo Unit - The Cryo process recovers valuable liquid hydrocarbons from the No 5 FCC and Alky tail gas streams before they are introduced into the refinery fuel gas system.  Products of mixed liquid hydrocarbon stream are propane and heavier components and a residue gas stream containing the ethane and methane. High & low shutdowns and alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie. regeneration gas compressor, fuel gas compressor,  & refrigerant compressor & associated drivers) in this process combined with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public,and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 5 FCC Process - The Fluidized Catalytic Cracking process converts gas oil (a viscous material similar to motor oil) into blendstocks used to make gasoline and diesel fuel.  Co-products include: heating oil, slurry, butane, and lighter products to be used by other processes in the refinery.  High & low shutdowns & alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie. air blower & centrifugal wet gas compressor and associated drivers) in this process along with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Butamer Process - Normal butane is converted to iso-butane in this process.  Light ends are removed in the stabilizer tower while the bottoms being sent back to the fractionation section for separation of iso & normal butane with debutanized gasoline sent to storage. High & low shutdowns & alarms on the combined gas compressor & driver with all of the  prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of  catastrophic failures.

Catalytic Polymerization - This process produces gasoline blending component (Poly gasoline) and propane from a feed charge containing mostly propane and propylene.  The feed stream (P-P stream) is produced from the FCC, Vapor Recovery unit.  The olefin compound (propylene) combines to form gasoline boiling range compounds in a polymerization reaction.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Coker Gas Plant: C3+ components (propane, propylene, butane, butylenes, and gasoline) are recovered and H2S is removed from various refinery hydrocarbon gas streams.  The recovered C3+ components are processed by other refinery units into LPG (propane and butane) and gasoline for blending.  The treated lean gas stream (without the C3+ components and H2S) is used as fuel gas in the refinery.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this PSM covered process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 8 Hydrotreater:  The No 8 Hydrotreater uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur and nitrogen from naphtha streams that are being used for Product Blending.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Fuel Gas Amine - This process removes hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas from various fuel gas streams within the plant.  Sweet fuel gas is sent to the fuel gas system.  All of the  prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 6 Hydrotreater - This process uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur from distillate streams.  Feed streams include Heating oil distillate, light cycle oil, cracked/virgin gas oil & desulfurized recycle distillate.  Unstable distillate & desulfurized distillate are sent to other processes in the facility.  High & low shutdown & alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie.Hydrogen compressor & associated driver) in this process incorporated with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 2 Cryo - This process recovers propylene & heavier components from the hydrogen-rich offgas streams from the HF Alky , No 2 CRU, No 2 HDS, No 3 CRU, No 4 HDS, No 5 HDS & No 6 HDS.  Liquified propane for the Sat Gas process is produced along with condensed hydrocarbons sent to the No 4 HDT.  High & low shutdowns and alarms on major pieces of rotating equipment (ie. expander/compressors & associated drivers) in this process combined with all of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

SHP Unit - The Selective Hydrogenation Process upgrades the feedstock to the alkylation process.  This upgrade decreases the consumption of HF acid and reduces the formation of acid soluble oil.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

West Plant Tank Farm - Propane and Propylene from the process area is sent to the underground salt cavern and storage bullets.  All of the  prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this PSM covered process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

South Plant Tank Farm - Butane & Isobutane from the process area is sent to storage spheres.  All of the  prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this PSM covered process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

HF Alkylation Process - The HF Akylation Process utilizes hydrogen flouride (HF) as a catalyst to promote the reaction of olefin with isobutane to form high octane gasoline blending components.  This process yields high octane gasoline, butane, & propane.  Strict adherance to API 751, Guidelines For Safe Operation of a Hydrofluoric Acid Alkylation Process, in addition to utilizing all the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary and with the support of  multiple HF detection monitors, deluge system protection (in addition to water spray) & 24 hour monitored cameras protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 1 Crude Process - The No 1 crude process is the first major refinery process encountered by crude oil which separates crude oil by fractional distillation.   Resulting raw products from this process include: light straight run gasoline for the SGP, naphtha, kerosene, heating oil distillate, and various gas oils, for storage or feed to other processes.  The prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 4 Crude Process - This process is similar  in operation to the No 2 & No 1 Crude processes.  Resulting raw products include: light end vapors, light straight run gasoline, kerosene, & feed to other processes.  The prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Delayed Coker - Thermal decomposition of hydrocarbon feedstock to the coker produces solid carbon (coke) and a range of other materials. The coke is transported to other manufacturers for use in making carbon electrodes.  The benefits of this coking process is the recovery of additonal gas oils by "cracking" the heavier portion of the crude barrel.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 4 Hydrotreater - The No 4 Hydrotreater uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur from kerosene.  The feeds can fluctuate depending on product economics.  Outputs from this include desulfurized kerosene product, naptha, recycled hydrogen, & off gas to area fuel gas amine contactor.  All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 5 Hydrotreater - The No 5 Hydrotreater uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur and nitrogen from gas oil streams that are being sent to the No 5 FCC for processing.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 7 Hydrotreater:  The No 7 Hydrotreater uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur and nitrogen from gasoline streams that are being used for Product Blending.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

Product Blending - Products from the process area are mixed with additives (including Butane) to create various grades of diesel, gasoline, and aviation fuels.  All of the  prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this PSM covered process to protect refinery workers, the public, and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 2 Isomerization:  The No 2 Isomerization Unit increases the octane of light straight run (LSR) gasoline.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.

No 9 Hydrotreater:  The No 9 Hydrotreater uses hydrogen in the presence of catalyst to remove sulfur and nitrogen from distillate streams that are being used for Distillate Blending.   All of the prevention program steps described in the Executive Summary are utilized in this process to protect refinery workers, the public and the environment from consequences of catastrophic failures.
West Plant Oil Recovery Unit

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery has a long-standing commitment to protecting the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances; however, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to, control and contain the release. 



DESCRIPTION OF OUR FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED 



The Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery, located in Ponca City, Kay County, Oklahoma, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g., propane, butane, gasoline, and diesel) from raw crude oil. The refinery has several regulated substances meeting the threshold quantities (TQs) as defined in 68.115. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS 



The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery. Because processes at the refinery that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program. 



Employee Participation 



The Ponca City Refinery employees participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the refinery accident pr

evention program. Specific ways that employees are involved are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the refinery and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, the refinery has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and employee safety issues. These initiatives include forming teams to promote both process and personal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and plant management. 



Process Safety Information 



The Ponca City Refinery keeps a variety of technical documents that are important to the safe operation and maintenance of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. The primary delivery tool for information is the electronic document management system. Personnel have access to many stations from which to retrieve this information. This information is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate any necessary process safety information. 



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. 



For specific process areas, the refinery has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in the Process Technology Package Safe Operating Limits (Section 1.4) and the Reliability Operating Limits (Section 1.5). The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protecti

ve instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 



The refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials used in construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



The Ponca City Refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. 



Primarily the "guide word" HAZOP analysis technique is used to perform PHA evaluations, in conjunction with safety checklists. This analysis provides a systematic and thorough hazard evaluation technique that brings different points of view to identify potential hazards. The analyses are conducted using a team of people incorporating operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. PHA leaders are certified. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) has been incorporated into PHA studies to help improve risk reduction. 



The PHA team findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assig

ned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked electronically until they are physically complete. 



To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate from the original design safety features, the Ponca City Refinery revalidates the hazard analysis results every 5 years. This will continue at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. During this 5-year period, PHAs are conducted in the operating units as required by the Management of Change (MOC) process. 



Operating Procedures 



The Ponca City Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown/operations, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. The Refinery documents Safe Operating Limits (SOLs) and provides guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedances for specific process or equipment parameters. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks. 



Training 



To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Ponca City Refinery provides a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in refinery operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests and skills demonstration) adequate knowledge to perf

orm the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators receive refresher training at least every 3 years on operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. Refresher training emphasizes process overview information, operating issues, safe work practices, and operating procedures that are rarely used such as emergency shutdown, emergency operation and startup following an emergency shutdown. Operators receive training on Emergency Shutdown procedures annually. A Training Needs Analysis (TNA) document lists the needed training to be performed for a specific job within the operating unit and also verifies the training has taken place by the trainee and supervisor signing and dating the document. 



Contractors 



The Ponca City Refinery uses contractors to supplement its work force. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. 



This is accomplished by contractor employees attending safety orientation sessions covering: (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) the emergency response plan requirements and (4) review / discussion of safe work practices prior to their beginning work through the use of Job Safety Analysis (JSAs). 



In addition, the Ponca City refinery evaluates contractor safety programs (safety organization, employee education and training and accident prevention programs) and their prior performance (using OSHA injury rates, property loss experience, regulatory compliance history and workers comp exper

ience) during the selection of a contractor. Refinery personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. 



Contractors are also required to be registered with ISNetworld. ISNetworld provides a records verification service which reviews the health and safety procedures that each contractor has in place based on the type of work the contractor performs for the Ponca City Refinery. 



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 



The Ponca City Refinery conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a physical change to the process. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides a means to ensure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that support systems have been tested and are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. Our checklist contains a list of safety questions covering process considerations that must be addressed prior to startup and provides the names of the reviewer responsible for confirmation of each pre-startup safety question. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented and training has been completed and documented. 



Mechanical Integrity 



The Ponca City Refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, motors, safety instrument systems, and electrical systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (

5) applying quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials are used when repairs are made. 



Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency if conditions allow, or a technical assessment will be conducted to review the continued use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure continued safe operation of the equipment until appropriate repairs or replacement can be made. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. 



Safe Work Practices 



The Ponca City Refinery has numerous safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a Hazardous Energy Control (lockout/tagout) procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. 



Work permit forms are periodically audited by refinery personnel to ensure the information is accurate and

well documented. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 



Management of Change



The Ponca City Refinery has a thorough system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. 



Changes are reviewed to: (1) confirm that the technical basis for the change is appropriate, (2) ensure the safety and health impacts of the change are understood, (3) verify that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, (4) insure that existing controls have not been compromised by the change, (5) establish the permissible time period for temporary changes, and (6) document that the change is authorized by the appropriate personnel. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, and procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. 



In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary notification and training needed due to the change. The Ponca City Refinery utilizes an eMOC process that includes specific workflows for each operating Area. The eMOC system includes logging userID data and date/time stamping workflow progress. A QC step and metrics provides a system to help ensure procedure steps are properly followed. 



Incident Investigation 



The Ponca City Refinery investigates incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, property damage, environmental effects, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team (trained in investigation techniques inc

luding root cause failure analysis) documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion. The investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHA revalidations. 



Compliance Audits 



To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Ponca City Refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. 



Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years with results certified by the Plant Manager. Both hourly and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. 



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 



The processes at the Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery contain hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all Program Level 3 EPA RMP-covered processes at the Refinery. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors. 



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the Refinery has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (or mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes: 



Release Detection 



* Hydrocarbon de

tectors with alarms 

* Cameras with 24 hour monitoring 

* Toxic detectors with alarms 



Release Containment/Control 



* Process relief valves that discharge to one of 4 different flare systems to capture and incinerate episodic releases 

* Scrubber to neutralize chemical releases 

* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated) 

* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature) 

* Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release (e.g., dump tank) 

* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases 

* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump and dual electrical feeds for all major substations) 

* Atmospheric relief devices (e.g. utilities) 

* Tandem pump seals on select pumps 



Release Mitigation

 

* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems 

* Deluge system for specific equipment 

* Trained emergency response personnel 

* Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, SCBA) 

* Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel 

* Instrument safety systems and independent alarms manned on a 24-hour basis 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 



There have been no RMP covered process incidents within the Ponca City Refinery over the past five (5) years. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 



The Phillips 66 Ponca City Refinery has implemented an effective Emergency Response (ER) program to protect the refinery worker, the public and the environment. The program consists of knowledgeable emergency responders, appropriate response equipment, and procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion. The ER program utilizes the Incident Command System (ICS) to manage all aspects of response. The three divisions of the Emergency Response Team include the Hazardous Materials (H

azmat) Team, Fire Brigade, and Rescue Team. 



The ER procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the Ponca City Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, testing and functional certification of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Emergency response employees receive training in these procedures to perform their specific duties. The emergency response program is reviewed annually and updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or other refinery facilities. The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.



The overall emergency response program for the Ponca City Refinery is coordinated with the Kay County, Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) as well as local fire departments and law enforcement agencies. This coordination includes periodic meetings with local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The Refinery has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Ponca City Refinery conducts periodic emergency drills with the LEPC, local emergency response organizations, and local medical providers. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



The following changes will be made to improve the containment, control and release mitigation of chemicals covered by the RMP:

* Upgrade and expand the PCR Central Control Room (Main Control Center for the entire plant)

* Upgrade the Distributive Control System (DCS) across the refinery

* Upgrade of additional selected pumps to tandem seals 

* Continuing improvement of the Management of Change process 

* Screen existing piping for corrosion under insulation 

* Perform soil-to-air interface inspection of underground in-service piping 

* Revise the plant-wide process for Unit Isolation Valves to document the "back-up" valves to be used if the initial ones are not accessible due to the extent of an incident. 

* Install automatic emergency isolation valves in new identified processes 

* Upgrade safety instrumented systems on fired heaters 

* Upgrade underground cavern storage emergency isolation 

* Implement processes to improve alarm management

* Implement improvements to our Mechanical Integrity programs that govern sulfidation corrosion, High Temperature Hydrogen Attack (HTHA) and the use of small bore piping.

* Add layers of testing in our Positive Material Identification program
